title: Popular bank AXING key service from today in blow to 1.9million customers

content:
Plus, we share more banking changes

BANK BLOW Popular bank AXING key service from today in blow to 1.9million customers – are you affected?

AN online bank with 1.9 million customers is making a huge change to accounts.

First Direct customers will no longer be sent paper saving account statements as of today, September 1.

Instead, customers will be able to view, download and print their statements using the bank's app or online banking.

The change will only affect those who have a savings account with the bank.

It comes after the bank sent an email to customers back in July explaining the change.

Customers have expressed their frustration with the change.

One saver said: “Been with @firstdirect for 25 years. They’re fine except for ONE thing. I want a paper statement.”

Another posted on Facebook: “I just got an email from first direct telling me they will no longer send me paper bank statements.”

The change will happen automatically so customers do not need to do anything.

Plus, other information may still be sent to customers by post.

Customers will receive an email as soon as their new statement is ready, so they should make sure their details are up to date.

To do this, visit the "profile" section of the app or "my details" section of online banking.

When they receive the email, customers need to log on to view the new statement.

To find it in the app, they just need to click the three dots next to their account.

The switch is not final and customers who still want paper statements will still be able to change back after September 1.

To do so, they will need to log into online banking, click on “my details” then go to “statement preferences”.

If they need help, then they can contact customer services in the “message us” section of online banking.

Alternatively, they can get in touch with First Direct customer services by going to the help section of its app.

And First Direct is not the only bank making changes for customers.

Nationwide also switched to paperless bank statements last month.

Customers will instead need to log in to their banking app or go on the website to check their statements.

You can still opt in to get paper statements but they won't be sent out automatically any more.

Lloyds Banking Group, which owns Lloyds, Halifax and Bank of Scotland, did the same in 2023.

The change came in for customers who had online banking set up.

Elsewhere, NatWest also increased its fees for cash payments, cheque transactions and certain online transactions.

As of August 30, cash payments into and out of business accounts will see their fees increase from 70p per £100 to 95p per £100.

Cheque payments will also jump from 70p to 75p, irrespective of whether they are processed by hand or mobile.

The bank will also hike some charges connected to its BACS payment system, with processing fees rising from 18p to 21p.
summary: First Direct, an online bank with 1.9 million customers, is discontinuing sending paper saving account statements as of September 1. Instead, customers will be able to view, download and print their statements using the bank's app or online banking. This change will only affect customers with a savings account. Customers can still opt in to receive paper statements but they won't be sent out automatically. The change is not final and customers can change their paper statements after September 1, although they can change back after that. Other information may still be sent to customers by post.
shortSummary: First Direct will stop sending paper accounts to customers, allowing instead to view and print statements using the app or online banking platforms.

argos_summary: First Direct will stop mailing paper savings statements from September 1, offering digital access instead, a change mirrored by Nationwide and Lloyds. Customers can still opt for paper if they change preferences. Meanwhile, NatWest has raised fees for cash, cheque, and BACS transactions, increasing costs for business accounts.
